page.title: 03Climate
page.content: The area is exposed and thus windy, but is saved from excessive cold by the moderating effect of the Trent Valley. Its climate is closest to that of the SE of England but somewhat colder because of latitude and height. The average annual rainfall is 625 mm, and annual sunshine about 1350 hours. The growing season extends from early April to late November. There is some risk of drought during dry summers. 1985 has, however, been cooler and less sunny than average so there was no shortage of moisture in the soil until the autumn, when the dry Sep- tember caused the farmers to complain that they could not get on with sowing winter wheat, the heavy clay soil having become baked.
